characters: ON HIS UGLY FACE BIG IN THE GLASS
A TEN-FOOT ELECTRIC-BLUE ITALIAN LEATHER COUCH
CAMERA EASES OVER TO THE WINDOW
AS THE CAMERA COMPLETES A CIRCLE OF THE ROOM
ON THE SCREEN OF AN OLD TV SET

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crisp and perfect New England town.  Almost too neat to be real.  No visible townspeople.  CAMERA EXPLORES town.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FLIES
dialogues.text: over a rickety bridge -- PAST the Maitland Hardware and Appliance store -- PAST the church -- the Historical Society -- UP over the graveyard on the hill and finally -- To the Maitland house.  The perfect Victorian house surveying the tiny village.  Suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: A GIANT DADDY LONGLEGS SPIDER
dialogues.text: mounts the crest of the hill beside the house, pauses to wave a spindly leg and then creeps menacingly on top of the Maitland house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, you're a big fella...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand -- as big as God's -- with a huge tweezer, gently reaches down out of the sky and lies, palm up, in the yard next to the house.  Daddy Longlegs climbs into it.  The hand rises into the sky again.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Reveals Winter River as a miniature town, while The Daddy Longlegs and the hand are normal size.  Above the model are a homely representation of moon, sun, and stars -- a whole, tiny, mechanical universe to track the hours of the day.  A large plat map of the city is prominent on the wall. The hand is ADAM MAITLAND'S.  In his late 30's, he's a solid easy-going citizen.  Capra used to make movies about him. Adam's model town sprawls across most of the attic space.  Windows on either end of the attic shed good light into the warm room.  Adam very carefully lifts the spider out the open window.  Smiles as he drips him lightly on the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see the real Winter River, laid out exactly as the model, at the foot of the hill.  Adam breathes deeply and looks very pleased at the glorious town below him.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS HUGE HAND AGAIN
dialogues.text: as it reaches into model and tweezes a tiny sign into the tiny window of Maitland's Hardware Store on main street.  It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam leans down and eyes the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (behind him) I'm ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam turns to see entering:  BARBARA MAITLAND, 35 -- a wholesome beauty who is mellowing well.  She smiles at him.  Perhaps a certain tinge of sadness about her, because they don't have children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happy to see her) She's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing the model) It looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes a wrapped present across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy vacation, honey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam smiles and gives her a present he's hidden under the table.  He opens his present.  A can of furniture oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manchurian Tung oil? (playfully grabs Barbara and kisses her) Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen got it for me in Oslo. There's enough to refinish the gateleg table and the cherry wardrobe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam hands Barbara a carefully-wrapped bundle -- she unwraps her gift... rolls of very expensive floral wallpaper.  She cradles it in her arms like gold leaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Adam... it's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam nods, and embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to do the guest room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cooing) I'm so glad we're spending our vacation at home... (with a sudden resolve) ... I'm going to get started right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling her back) Whoa!... hold on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara calms down, returning to Adam's embrace... as: PHONE RINGS -- They freeze, then grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unison) No one's home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HONK HONK outside.  They look at each other horrified. Peer out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at her) It's your turn, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head with resignation and goes downstairs. KNOCKING on door from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Adam and Barbara downstairs.  We see the rambling, old fashioned quality to the house. Clean, sentimental, warm and floral.  Some rooms in progress.  They continue down the main staircase past photos of themselves, old photos of the early days of Winter River, pictures and mementos of three generations in hardware.  Barbara goes to the kitchen and Adam continues down to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN
dialogues.text: JANE BUTTERFIELD -- tall, gawky and aggressive peeks in the kitchen door.  She's divorced three husbands and buried another for good measure.  She's ruthless but is weirdly, seamlessly pleasant.  She waves a legal sized paper at them, starts to come inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara makes dash for it and holds it just as Jane gets a foot in.  Jane smiles wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Barb!  I'm glad I caught you. I heard you were on vacation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Jane.  Complete vacation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey -- today I am three hundred fifty thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Jane, it is 6:45 in the morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, think of me as cash! This offer is really real!  From a rich man in New York City who only saw a photograph! (rattles on) My buyer has just made a killing in condos in Manhattan, but he's got a little stress problem... (taps her head) ... so -- he wants to bring the wife and kid for the old peace and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're looking for, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara Maitland, sweetie, just listen now.  This house is too big.  It really ought to be for a couple with a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hurts Barbara a little.  She looks at Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, honey... I didn't mean anything... it's just too big for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane compulsively affixes her business card, face inside. in the windowpane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shutting door) 'Bye, Jane, see you in a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: is humming happily, looking for paint brushes in the ground floor storeroom.  He spies a cassette deck and looks through a stack of cassettes and plays one.  It is an old INKSPOTS LOVE SONG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is starting to paper the walls already.  She frowns at the MUSIC.  Goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey.  You said no Inkspots on this vacation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It CLICKS OFF.  She goes back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam puts away the tape but keeps humming the song.  He opens the shutters on a small window.  ON WINDOW...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her huge face grinning at him) Boo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps back, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam closes the shutters as Jane affixes yet another card to the window.  He continues his search for a brush.

dialogues.speaker: JANE
dialogues.text: exits jauntily, flapping her contract down the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam continues rummaging for a brush.  Can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to distant Barbara) Honey, come with me down to the store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a good brush for this Tung oil and I want to pick up a piece of the model.  Let's go early before anyone sees us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara has already papered a few rolls in the guest room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but let's hurry back.  You just run in okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Victorian house from the model "in the flesh." Adam stands by the station wagon. On the bumper of the car is a sticker reading: WARNING:  I BRAKE FOR ANIMALS. Barbara gets in driver's side.  They drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam dusts the inside of the dashboard.  Clean Clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Jane said we should sell the house to someone with a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the ever-tactful Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts his hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the car coming down the hill toward the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be flattered that she wants to sell our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... I just wish she'd leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not think about it.  We'll have a nice romantic, quiet, vacation.  Here comes the bridge chorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car reaches the rickety covered bridge.  Car shakes, bobbing up and down on every plank. ON Barbara and Adam TIGHT -- (they've done this routine before).  They sing an old Johnny Mathis song.  With a lot of vibrato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chances are... When I wear a foolish grin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like the model, but real.  And populated. CAMERA PAUSES ON a gorgeous storefront with a brass lion out front.  Sign above doors says -- BOZMAN BUILDING 1835

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old man polishes the lion as Maitlands drive by and wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wave at the lion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget the balls, Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Adam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie looks around to see no one's looking and polishes the balls of the lion.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA SPIES A JAUNTY DOG
dialogues.text: like Benji, peeing on the opposite corner of the lion. Maitlands drive by store with sign: JANE BUTTERFIELD ANTIQUES REAL ESTATE TRAVEL

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The store is bursting with antiques of all sorts, travel brochures, photographs of houses for sale, and a serve-yourself Xerox machine.  LITTLE JANE, her eight- year-old daughter is drudgingly making copies. Jane, phone in hand, rushes to the window to watch Maitlands drive by.  Almost popping the cord when it reaches its end.  She's waiting for the other party to pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y... ello.  Mrs. Deetz?  Well the condition is what we country folk call, fixin'... Yes, I think they are fixin' to accept another offer.  Well maybe if you offer 390,000 they'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam sprints up the steps of his lovely hardware store. OLD BILL, a slightly-addled ancient barber, is napping in a chair in front of his shop, next door to Adam's. Adam fumbles with the lock, not interested in conver- sation.  He drops his keys, waking Old Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Adam.  You need a haircut before your vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the model coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, Bill -- Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill turns around and continues prattling even though Adam has entered.  Bill prattles throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, I was thinkin'... you said Bozman built the foundation in 1835 but y'know his grandson came in here last week and said he found a bottle with an 1836 stamp in it plastered in the foundation. (suddenly disgusted at the memory) He's got hair down to his goddamned shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam pulls down a few good paintbrushes and carefully picks up a small model of the Bozman building.  He walks out.  Old Bill continues unabated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said "Just give me a trim..." I took a scissors to him so fast... would've skimmed him clean if he hadn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam strides by quickly to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Maitlands drive their car out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five brushes sit on the seat next to Adam.  He cradles small replica of the Bozman building, complete with brass lion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah it turned out okay.  We applied for a historical plaque for it.  That'll be the third one on Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jokingly) With all these historical landmarks in town, where are they going to put the condominiums?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Slow down there, honey... I don't want the vibration to weaken the model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) Oh... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara starts to apply the brakes. Just before the bridge the dog waddles out in the road. Stops to pee.  Barbara swerves.  As the car hits the rickety bridge, the speed is just a bit too much. Boards RATTLE and loosen, the car skews and catches in an open slot, careens to the right, then the left and the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piling has smashed through the window on the pas- senger side, crushing the upper part of Barbara's arm.  She is wailing in pain and fright. Adam tries to help Barbara.  He tries to get out of the car.  None of this succeeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog finishes, looks over at the car, walks across the bridge and steps on the one board which holds the car aloft. The car rocks back and forth for a moment, and then slides forward toward the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car plunges into the rushing water.  It floats for a moment, and then sinks like a stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, still, expectant.  There is a fire laid in the hearth.  Suddenly and for no apparent reason it ignites and burns with a furious cheerfulness. Barbara and Adam enter, dazed, wet, and bedraggled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like this always happens when we try to go on vacation. Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam leads her toward the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll feel better when you're dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hands to be warmed.  Barbara comes up beside him.  All this time she's been holding her injured arm with the other hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fire wasn't burning when we left the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  It feels... frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds her arms out to warm them.  One hand catches on fire.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA'S LEFT ARM
dialogues.text: They stare at it dumbfoundedly before Adam regains his senses and snatches it out of the fire.  Two of the fingers are burning like candles, and Barbara indus- triously blows them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are sitting on the couch together.  Barbara is looking away slightly -- as one does when a doctor is drawing blood -- while Adam looks at her fingers.  He frowns. He looks at his skin.  It is pale.  He looks at Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better sit down, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what, Barbara.  I don't think we survived that crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Oh, Adam.  We're home.  In our own house.  Nonsense.  I'll make some coffee.  You get some more firewood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam gets up, a little absently, she follows him as he wanders to the front door.  He peers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take things extra slow.  Do you remember how we got back up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara tests her hand, clenches and unclenches her fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  My arm works fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, exploring, opens the door, steps out on the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's face is painted with color of sunset.  He stands atop the steps leading down to the front yard.  Barbara stands just inside the open threshold, looking out worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet sarcasm) The end of a perfect day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam starts to step down to the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm gonna go down to the bridge and retrace our steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps off the last step into the yard and promptly disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is nowhere.  There's no ground, no sky, nothing to stand on or hold onto or give boundaries or distance. Just vast nothing.  Not white and not colored either. NOISE OF A CLOCK TICKING. Adam looks about surprised, doesn't like what he doesn't see.  He turns around to head back up the steps.  There are no steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His VOICE ECHOES STRANGELY.  He runs off a little in the distance, and calls again from over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; quietly) Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes even farther away.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FOREGROUND
dialogues.text: an enormous geared wheel -- the size of a man -- rolls by, tearing up the unseamed ground.  Something pours up out of the tear -- ooze or stuffing. Adam runs forward and stares after the wheel, which is now out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: TWO SMALLER GEARS
dialogues.text: looking very much like components of a giant watch -- spin along behind him.  One of them veers suddenly toward him, and though Adam jumps out of the way, the gear snags his trouser leg and shreds it.  LOUD TICKING.

dialogues.speaker: A PERFECTLY ENORMOUS GEAR
dialogues.text: comes barreling toward him.  Adam leaps out of its way.  The gear turns, fish-tailing, kicking up ooze and stuffing. Adam flings himself suddenly to the right, but trips into the path of the gear.  As he's about to be crushed, he's suddenly jerked up to safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Barbara who's grabbed him, and quite evidently saved his life -- not life, perhaps -- but existence. He's shaken, breathless. Barbara stares at him, as if wondering what he's just been through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) You saved my -- uh -- life... or whatever...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how long you were gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pondering that) ... Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara leads Adam into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything happen while I was away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it did.  Yes, it did.  I made a couple of small discoveries.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: stands by the mirror over the hearth mantle.  On the mantle is Barbara's prize collection of porcelain horses.  Adam comes to stand beside her.  They look into the mirror, and there is no reflection of them. Barbara picks up one of the horses, and trots it through the air.  The horse is imaged in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) There's that, and there's this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up an ancient, leather-bound book.  It's yellow and worn, about the size of the Boy Scout manual. CLOSEUP:  Its title is HANDBOOK FOR THE RECENTLY DECEASED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Handbook for the recently diseased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deceased.  I don't know where it came from.  Look at the publisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he does and reads) Handbook for the Recently Deceased Press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally admit- ting it) I don't think we survived the crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is already in bed, reading from the handbook. Barbara is getting ready for bed -- going through a ritual of sorts that they practiced every night of their married lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like situations like this. I hate it when I'm not in control. So just tell me the basics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This book isn't arranged that way.  What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are a thousand things... Why did you disappear when you walked off the front porch?  Is this a punishment?  Are we halfway to heaven or are we halfway to hell? And how long is this going to last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see anything about "Rewards and Punishments" or "Heaven and Hell." (frustrated) This book reads like stereo instructions!  Listen to this... 'Geographical and Temporal Perimeters... Functional perimeters vary from manifestation to manifestation."  This is going to take some time.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: paces, she trips on her wallpaper rolls.  Kicks them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew I'd never finish the guest room.  Adam, we just can't stay in here forever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other, the question hangs in the air. Can't they? Adam stands and walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Maybe we should set up a normal routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him like he's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I mean, let's try to nail down something in our lives.  A regular schedule.  We can keep track of time and go on with our projects up here in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head, exasperated.  Flops down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God, maybe this is all just a bad dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ADAM - TIGHT - a somber look comes across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara looks up at him, questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  What's wrong?  Adam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands and joins him at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance we see an automobile funeral procession threading its way toward the nearby cemetery.  Head- lights are on.  We recognize Jane's car in the line.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON BARBARA AND ADAM
dialogues.text: somber faces.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHTER ON PROCESSION
dialogues.text: It arrives at the gravesite.  We see some familiar faces, Ernie, and Old Bill the Barber.  Jane and little Jane watch as two identical coffins are carried to- gether, to two open graves.

dialogues.speaker: ON BARBARA AND ADAM
dialogues.text: She drops her head sadly on his shoulder.  He leans his face slightly into hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is setting up a small monument in the model town cemetery.  It reads:  ADAM AND BARBARA MAITLAND/UNITED IN LIFE/UNDIVIDED IN DEATH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had a better view of the cemetery from up here.  I don't know which area is the best placement for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, trying to clean, lets out a frustrated YELP! She paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Cabin fever, han?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't clean anything.  The vacuum is out in the garage.  I can't leave the house.  Why don't they tell us something?  Where are all the other dead people in the world?  Why is it just you and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this is heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the dusty walls) In heaven there wouldn't be dust on the wallpaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hon... I didn't want to die, but really, this is fine with me. Look, we never have to wash dishes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dishes?  We haven't eaten in three weeks!  Adam, I'm not like you.  I really need to be around people, get out to the church and go grocery shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not hungry, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara shakes her head and picks up the Handbook and pages through it desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep having this feeling that something has got to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAR DOOR SLAMS outside.  Adam and Barbara look at one another.  Run to window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Butterfield is staring up at the old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, from his angle, can just barely see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (shouting) Jane, Jane, up here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unhearing, Jane heads for car.  SOUND OF WIND UP. Blows her dress.  Little Jane straggles along with her like an apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara watches Adam, and shakes her head.  He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't see you, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) In the book, Rule Number Two:  the living usually won't see the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't?  Or can't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just says "won't."  Wait a minute. Here it says "the living are arrogant... they think they'll never die, so they refuse to see the dead."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrogant.  That's Jane all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara sighs and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least we won't have to worry about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam smiles and goes to his model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane drives away.  CAMERA HINGES to see a FOR SALE sign.  Across it -- another smaller banner.  It reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Maitlands are asleep.  CAMERA EXPLORES the room a bit.  It is getting slightly tatty.  Adam rolls over, pulling the covers off Barbara.  We see: ON BARBARA -- she is hovering off the side of the bed. An OMINOUS RUMBLE -- like a 4.0 earthquake shakes the house.  GLASS RATTLES, the ceramic horses on the mantelpiece jump around.  Barbara falls to the floor. They look at one another with horror.  They leap up and run downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RUMBLE BUILDS TO A CLIMAX, there is a LOUD METALLIC SQUEAL, and then a CRASH... just as Barbara and Adam arrive.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: smashes open revealing a moving van ramp.

dialogues.speaker: A TEN-FOOT ELECTRIC-BLUE ITALIAN LEATHER COUCH
dialogues.text: slides smoothly down the ramp.  On the couch sits DELIA DEETZ. The couch CRASHES into the base of the staircase, smashing the newel post and several of the balusters. Barbara cringes.  One of the balusters falls at Delia's side.  She grasps it like a scepter. Two MOVING MEN rush down the ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that, Mrs. Deetz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  It was going anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia is relentlessly New York, relentlessly fashion- able, relentlessly thin -- totally self assured. She is also a woman with a mission -- to gut Barbara and Adam's house and remake it in her own very upscale image. Delia's gaze is on the living room, but she looks  through Adam and Barbara as if they weren't even there (which to her eyes they're not). Still holding the baluster, Delia gets up off the couch and moves into the living room, surveying it with an odd mixture of ambition, and resolution.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND HER
dialogues.text: the two Moving Men bring in a matching blue leather armchair.  In the armchair sits LYDIA DEETZ. Lydia, age 14, is a pretty girl, but wan, pale and overly-dramatic, dressed as she is in her favorite color, black.  She's a combination of a little death rocker and an 80's version of Edward Gorey's little girls. She has a couple of expensive cameras around her neck -- and is already taking photographs of the moving men.  Lydia is cool, Lydia is sullen, Lydia is her father's daughter by his first marriage.  Lydia is usually about half-pissed off.  But underneath... we like her a lot. The Moving Men still hold up the chair, waiting for Delia to decide where she wants it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Jesus.  Who lived here?  The Waltons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON Lydia -- calmly surveys the house. Delia signals wearily that the Moving Men can put the chair down anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Get all this other crap out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia hops down out of the chair, and comes farther into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where is your father?... probably in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the cue for CHARLES DEETZ, who comes in through the swinging door, and across the dining room... a ner- vous but basically pleasant man, CHARLES DEETZ is intent on attacking rest and relaxation with the same vengeance that earned him millions in real estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise in that kitchen.  Noisy refrigerator, noisy faucets... We'll have to replace it all.  I want no humming in the house.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: exploring on her own, gazes around the living room with growing pleasure, she backs up for a good angle to photograph. CAMERA HINGES -- She is standing with her back right up to Barbara -- who is horrified at this creature. Charles enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lydia) What do you think, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia hates it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia gazes at a dusty maze of spider webs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I could live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A movement makes Lydia turn around and scream.  It is Delia.  Not Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle down, Lydia.  I wonder where we are going to get counseling for you out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VIOLENT FALSETTO SCREAM turns the Deetz family's attention to the front windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  Oh help!

dialogues.speaker: OTHO'S MASSIVE BODY
dialogues.text: Wedged in the window frame.  The short, stubby legs, dressed in the world's largest pair of Georgia Armani slacks, protrude into the living room, waving fran- tically.  Expensive Italian loafers are kicked off the feet, revealing a pair of expensive patterned socks. By their feet shall ye know them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Otho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho, why didn't you just come in the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho's voice comes as if from a great distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bad luck.  And I believe hugely in luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your breath and we'll pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia turns to Charles and Lydia for help -- doesn't get it -- and at last pulls Otho into the living room single-handedly. All this while the Moving Men are variously carting out the handsome old furniture and bringing in the hideous new furniture. Otho is Robert Morley at his most obscenely fat and faggoty.  But he's not all fat and fun -- this customer carries nasty emotional weight as well.

dialogues.speaker: OTHO
dialogues.text: holds onto the curtains for support as he is pulled through the window.  And when he is at last all the way through, and upright on his feet, he suddenly gives a tremendous yank.  The whole drapery apparatus, including valences, crashes to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the single most unattractive window treatment I have ever seen in the entire of my existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starry eyed) I'm so glad you could leave the city to consult me, Otho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho is looking around the room with an eye of quiet horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course you are.  Well, Otho had an intuition.  Call it a hunch -- that it was going to be a fabled monstrosity of a house. And it certainly is.  Charles, you're lucky the yuppies are buying condos, so you can afford what I'm going to have to do to this place.  We are talking from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the ground ups'ville!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, Otho.  Just keep me out of it.  I am here to relax and clip coupons.  And goddamnit, I mean to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits to find solace in a quiet corner of his house. During this speech, Otho has been surreptitiously pos- ing for Lydia's camera.  She clicks the shutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) Is the rest of the house as bad as this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the house is probably worse.  When can you and I get started?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time like the present, as my wicked stepmother used to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the pockets of his size 56 Georgia Armani jacket, Otho takes two cans of spray paint -- the kind the graffiti artists use -- and shakes them as if they were castanets.  They certainly sound like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia, let's get this show on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one end, near the stairs leading up to the attic, Barbara and Adam are slumped against opposite walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, we are in hell.  I hate these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make Jane look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a punishment for something we did in life?  What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determined) We're not completely helpless. I've been reading the book. There's a word for people in our predicament, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ghosts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is shocked at the reality. Otho and Delia come up the stairs at the end of the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dealing with negative entertainment potential here.  I mean, there's absolutely no organic walking flow-through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho looks down the hallway.  It's empty.  Adam and Barbara are no longer there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I saw something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DeLia turns and spray-paints on the wall -- in luminous orange -- the word MAUVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming with delight) You read my mind!  I love clients who can read my mind.  I don't think people realize how strong a connection there is between interior design and the supernatural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fawning) I know... I read your book, The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haunted Tapestries of the Waldorf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia opens the door and they step inside another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be Lydia's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Lydia's room yet, of course, because it still has the Maitlands' furniture in it.  Barbara had partly wallpapered it before the accident.  Her tools are still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viridian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viridian?  What is...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho spray-paints the word VIRIDIAN on the wall -- plus the word BLUE GREEN -- and Cr2 03, right over a picture of Adam and Barbara as kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue-green!  Hydrated chromic oxide!  Remember I'm schooled in chemistry.  I was a hair analyst! Briefly.  Interior design is a science, Delia!  Think of me as Doctor Otho. (looking at wall) And this patient is truly sick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, her favorite color! How beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia smiles.  Behind Delia and Otho, the room's closet door swings slowly open with and ominous CREAK.

dialogues.speaker: DELIA AND OTHO
dialogues.text: turn that way, with a suggestion of dread.  Inside the closet, Barbara's corpse is suspended from the ceiling by a belt.  The corpse twists with a CREAK, and Barbara grins ghostly -- and slowly tears off her face, leaving nothing but muscle and bone beneath.  Her eyeballs dangle on her cheeks. Delia and Otho stare aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just have to pray that the other closets are bigger than this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over.  Looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Were these people dwarfes? (sic) (spies something) Oooooo!...  Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds, neatly hung in plastic, the Maitlands' wedding outfits.  Totally captivated by this powerful image, he peers through the plastic at them.  Holding each up to Delia.  Barbara watches wide-eyed at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Ozzie... (holding up her dress) ... and... Harriet!  What happened to these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia slams the door in Barbara's contorted face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia and Otho come out of Lydia's bedroom and go through the bathroom.  Disgusted, they continue on to the study.

dialogues.speaker: OTHO
dialogues.text: reaches out and turns the knob.  The door swings omi- nously open on Charles' study.  This had been Adam's reading and birdwatching study.  Bird posters on the wall, books everywhere.  Straight out of Better Homes and Gardens 1963.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooo.  Deliver me from L.L. Bean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one slight difference, however, because on the rag rug in the middle of the floor lies Adam's headless corpse.  Standing over him, holding in one hand a long knife and in the other Adam's blood-and-gore dripping head is Barbara -- with a maniacal look on her face. Behind them, Charles is thumbing through Adam's Audubon collection.  He sits up like a cornered animal protect- ing his territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Otho and Delia) This room is off limits.  I don't want either of you to touch one piece of furniture in here.  This is my room.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE ROOM
dialogues.text: The eyes of Adam's severed head open and look up at Barbara -- she stops screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't see us.  They can't hear us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, Delia is shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman who lived here had the aesthetic instincts of Betty Crocker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot convey to you the extent to which this house bores me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around scientifically) Once you cover up the wallpaper, knock down a few walls, alter the traffic patterns, and -- perhaps -- think about an inground pool -- the place might just be livable. What's on the third floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attic space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see.  We could turn that into a media room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head up the stars to the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's head has a look of terror on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.  I forgot to lock the attic door!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's headless body jumps up off the floor and rushes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho and Delia climbing.  The headless corpse careens past them, around the bend in the stairs and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you feel something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I felt a cool wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expression on Otho's face suggests he knows more than he's telling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headless corpse rushes through the open door into the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headless corpse slams the door shut, turns the key in the lock.  Then he slumps against the locked door in an exaggerated stance of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia tries the knob.  The door is locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Charles does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a feeling there's some very interesting space behind this door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Probably the world's largest Reader's Digest collection! C'mon, let's have some chablis, Otho, I'm laid bare by this experience.  Entirely bare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara still holding Adam's head. Charles still calmly leafing through the Audubons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew!  That was close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot witness this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara distractedly puts Adam's head on a bookshelf. His headless body fumbles with the books and finally reattaches the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam turns away from the window. Barbara, fuming, moves around Charles making wild gestures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the good of being a ghost if you can't frighten people to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not putting up with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She storms out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara storms in, as if straight from the room up- stairs.  She heads straight for the back door.  Just as she opens the door, Adam rushes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, honey!  Don't go out there.  You don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing can be worse than this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flings open the door and steps outside.  She promptly disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara plunges into the dusty surface of Titan with an enormous Saturn looming in the sky.  She looks around with wonder and some fear.

dialogues.speaker: A SULFUR VOLCANO
dialogues.text: erupts in the distance.  A meteor CRASHES with a lurid EXPLOSION.  As from a great distance she hears Adam's VOICE.  Like THUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns slowly in the yellow dense sand that covers the surface of this distant moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is trudging towards her.  Behind him, hovering isolated in the air, is the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Adam at last catches up with her.  Surveys around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Adam.  Find somebody.  I'm getting all yellow.  Do something!

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND THEM
dialogues.text: Something is burrowing rapidly toward them through the sand.  The Something could be right out of "Dune".

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA AND ADAM
dialogues.text: stare for a moment, then Adam grabs her and pulls her toward the kitchen door.  But the kitchen door has moved, so they veer in the new direction. The Something follows them and rises out of the sand.

dialogues.speaker: ON SOMETHING
dialogues.text: It is a very big, very nasty, and very hungry SNAPPING SANDWORM.  It ROARS and lunges at them.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: slightly angered at it, instinctively bats at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE SANDWORM
dialogues.text: is momentarily stunned at Barbara's audacity.  It freezes and shakes its loathesome head.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: bats at it again.  Adam is wide-eyed, tries to pull her away.  The Sandworm recovers and ROARS after them.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: grabs Barbara and tries to escape, but they slip and sink in the sand. They make it to the door just in time, swing it open and hurl themselves through.  The door shuts with a BANG just in front of the ROARING SANDWORM.

dialogues.speaker: THE SANDWORM
dialogues.text: rears and ROARS in frustration, HOWLING to the ringed planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, weeping, throws herself in Adam's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Adam, don't ever leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hugs him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I just realized that I could have been killed alone.  Don't ever leave me, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both contemplate that horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We're trapped in this house forever... with those... people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't say that for sure.  It could be a transitional thing. Like a post-life crisis.  We just have to be tougher with them. Come on.  Have some brandy. Spirits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tentative smile) Death didn't improve your sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam has his arms around Barbara's shoulder.  They walk in the door and stumble upon the Deetzes at their dinner.  Lydia's back is to them.  Barbara and Adam back out of the room but stop to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Deetz's around the dining room table.  There are candles and good china laid out-- but they're eating out of Chinese take-out boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that we're eating Cantonese.  Is there no Szechuan up here?  Hunan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one Chinese restaurant out here, darling, the owners are Irish and Irish people happen to cook Cantonese.  They don't know better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I plan to have a stroke from the amount of MSG that's in this food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our first meal in this house, Lydia.  Why don't we all do our little private parts to make it a pleasant one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, relax.  We'll build you a darkroom in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dramatically) My whole life is a darkroom! One... big... dark... room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia rolls her eyes and nods.  She's been through this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense... you'll go to school, maybe meet a farm boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia laughs.  Charles smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doleful) Yeah, maybe if he's nice, he'll let me hang myself from a rope in his barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, in a couple of years this whole town will be filled with people like us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be the art center of summer New York.  I'll start sculpting again... I'll teach those gallery bastards to refuse my sculpture. And when Otho and I get through with this house, you people are not going to recognize it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dramatically) I say let's keep it the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia stares at Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Good idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia shifts her glare to Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  I really like it.  I mean, it's already sort of like somebody's home, isn't it?  Their couch is comfortable and doesn't stick to your legs.  It smells like a real home, not a French whorehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, at your age, you are so

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: young. (back to business) Charles, we need to call that awful Jane Butterfield tomorrow and get the key to the attic door. Can't you find a way to hold back some of her commission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have a lot to do tomorrow... The Goodwill truck is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and whatever is up there in that attic goes away with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should have it fumigated, too.  I saw a fly today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia looks at them with a mixture of sadness and anger.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE DOOR
dialogues.text: -- listening, sit Barbara and Adam.  A tear rolls down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara are lying down on the floor, peering out of one of the small windows overlooking the front yard of the house.  The handbook open in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The entire front yard is alive with workmen and their vehicles.  Plumbers, electricians, cable TV men, etc. In the road on front of the house are several cars of rubbernecking locals, astonished by all the activity. The City has come to Town.  Moving men continue to move in the Deetz' modern, expensive and ugly furniture. They collide with Goodwill men coming out with the Maitlands' lovely antiques and personal possessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara just look at one another as if to say "We're next!"  Adam leafs through the handbook furi- ously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look in the index...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really...  what's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam pulls from the book an ancient, yellowed, crumbling handbill.  He carefully opens it. ON handbill -- very primitive, crude, red printing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Having difficulty adjusting? Is death a problem and not a solution?  Unhappy with eternity? Troubled by the living?  Call Betelgeuse, the bio-exorcist. That's Betelgeuse,  Betel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remainder of the sheet is torn off. ON Barbara -- fingering the torn edge.  Looking in the book for the remainder.  No luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?  No number, or instructions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  The bio-exorcist?  I don't get it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, away from the chaos outside is calmly steeping a mug of herb tea.  His solitude is interrupted by a 2500 lb. Vulcan range breaking through a too-small kitchen window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting through the window) What the hell are you trying to do out there?

dialogues.speaker: DELIA
dialogues.text: is berating the inept crane operator and shrieks periodically at some fine art movers who are struggling under her horrid modern welded steel sculptures.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: snaps photos of the mayhem.  She stops to scan the whole house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When her gaze reaches to top of the house, she suddenly glimpses Barbara and Adam's faces in the window.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Lydia blinks hard.  Her mouth drops open.  She looks all around -- as if she'd just seen a ghost or two.

dialogues.speaker: JANE BUTTERFIELD'S CAR
dialogues.text: pulls up.  Little Jane sits in the front seat, burdened with an enormous stack of collated and stapled copies. Lydia catches sight of Jane and runs over. Little Jane locks her door, in fear of Lydia-the strange.  Lydia stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a boy or a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only speak to vertebrates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the people who used to live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ratty little voice) They drowned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, they were family.  I was devastated. (beat) Here, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane hands a key to Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Is this the key to the attic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a skeleton key.  It'll open any door in that house.  Will you give it to your father? (handing her a business card) And you might mention that I single-handedly decorated the house.  In case he needs advice in that area.  Come see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane goes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia's face sobers as she looks up at the now empty attic window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help!  Get off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia drops the skeleton key into her pocket surrepti- tiously.  She follows Delia's SHRIEKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia rounds the corner to see Delia, pinned flat against the house by one of her horrid steel sculp- tures.  Two movers are struggling to free her.  Lydia snaps a quick photograph. They finally free Delia.  She clutches at her head, just short of tearing her hair out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You jerks!  That is my art, and it is dangerous!  You think I want to want to die like that? (seeing Lydia) Lydia.  Moving is a family affair. So buckle down now and go get Mommy some drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any particular kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joke!  Joke!  Aspirin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia walks off toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is half-hiding on the edge of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little girl saw us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She couldn't have.  We can't make them see us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she saw us.  I could feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, thinking that over) That's all we need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia looks up the stairs at the attic landing.  She's a little scared.  She decides to go up the dark stairs.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALL
dialogues.text: At the end of the hall stands Charles, directing men who are carrying books into the room that will be his study. He continues on. A BLAST of STEAM fills the hallway, because workmen are already going at the wallpaper.  Lydia emerges from it.  Looking up at stairway to attic, mounting courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia creeps upward, taking the skeleton key from her pocket.  FLOORBOARDS SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam works on his model.  He hears the SQUEAK, looks up confidently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Don't worry.  I've locked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara smiles and knits while rocking in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia quietly inserts the key in the lock of the attic door.  She turns it.  The key is stiff.  She turns harder.  It's stuck.  Lydia tries the door -- it's no go.  She turns the key again.  This time it goes all the way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam, surprised by the key, look at each other, carefully, very quietly, stand up and tiptoe toward door.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SCREEN OF AN OLD TV SET
dialogues.text: in the corner of the attic -- Suddenly -- a ghostly image POPS ON.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: outfitted in a too-big cowboy hat, bad wig, and over- sized sunglasses appears on screen singing very quickly.  (It's a heavily disguised BETELGEUSE.)

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND HIM
dialogues.text: the CAMERA QUICKLY PANS an assortment of tombstones a la Cal Worthington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Have the living got you down? Betelgeuse! Are they jacking you around? Betelgeuse! Have you broken out in hives 'Cause you're tired of their jive? I will drive them from your hive... Betelgeuse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA TILTS DOWN a flashing tombstone with "BETELGEUSE" written on it.  Adam rushes over to shut it off.  He can't find a plug.  He looks around behind set... no workings inside at all.  He peers around to the screen.  It is blank.  Suddenly -- Betelgeuse POPS ON AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it once... Betelgeuse Say it twice... Betelgeuse. The third time's a charm... Betelgeuse! Come on down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He POPS OFF.  Adam and Barbara stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia listens.  Did she hear something?  She puts her hand on the knob and tries to turn it.  It's stuck. Then the key eerily pops out of the lock and falls on the floor. Charles' head suddenly appears behind her.  Scares her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is holding on tight to the knob of the door.  With her knitting needle, Barbara has poked the key out. The two stand absolutely still, listening, terrified of the living intruders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to open the door.  Mrs. Butterfield brought over a skeleton key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam tighten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands her father the key.  He looks at it and throws it in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skeleton keys never work.  Anyway, this can wait.  We'll get a crowbar later.  Where's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quick de- cisive delivery) Stepmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going down to relax.  I want a noise-free zone.  Do you understand?  Noise-free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated, over his shoulder) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLAST OF STEAM from below drowns out her words. Charles stops and turns around.  The BLAST STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON LYDIA
dialogues.text: She is resolved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles continues.  She begins to follow slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ON KEY
dialogues.text: behind Lydia.  WIDEN as Adam rushes out the door, grabs the key and rushes back in again.  Lydia hears some- thing but doesn't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam have moved away from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking through the handbook) We need some help.  I found something this morning.  Here. Emergencies. (reads) "In case of emergency, draw door."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw door?  I don't know why we keep looking in that stupid book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam takes a piece of chalk and draws a little door on the exposed brick of the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't actually think this is going to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam draws a doorknob.  Then he tries to turn it.  The door, perhaps to his surprise, fails to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet another triumph for Adam and Barbara in the afterlife.  Why don't we try this Beetle guy??...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at book, then writes on the door:  KNOCK AND ENTER.  He exchanges a glance with Barbara.  She's even more skeptical than before.  Turns away in disgust. Adam knocks on the door, and turns the knob.  Nothing. She is more disgusted.  Adam goes back to the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Aha!  Knock three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knocks three times.  Turns knob.  The chalked door swings magnificently open. Behind is an eerie light source, SOARING MUSIC, maybe even a heavenly choir singing pear-shaped syllables. Barbara and Adam look at one another again.  They hold hands and step tentatively through. Their figures are lost in the blinding light. They start to shut door after them.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE ATTIC LANDING
dialogues.text: Lydia is staring at the light pouring from under the attic door.  It suddenly goes out.

dialogues.speaker: ON LYDIA
dialogues.text: She is dumbfounded.  She listens.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE LANDING
dialogues.text: Lydia speeds down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, fiercely intent on relaxing, paces like a catfish out of water.  Ralph Lauren in K-mart.  He stretches.  He sits uneasily in an easy chair, tries like hell to get comfortable.  Finally, he puts a book under his bottom to get sitting straight.  Looks around tapping his fingers.  What to do?  Looks at watch. He takes down a book from Adam's library, it is an Audubon book of birds.  He whips through it like it's the comics and then looks around for more. He finds the "Illustrated Walden" by Thoreau.  He speed reads it. He is now really bored.  Goes to the fireplace, tries to light it.  Cannot do it.  Goes to desk and writes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He studies bird posters.  Finds beautiful cardinal picture. Takes field glasses and looks out window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spies big ugly-looking ratty bird devouring something.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHARLES
dialogues.text: horrified.  Wrinkles his nose. Lydia enters.  He jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Darling, can't you see I'm relaxing in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I just wanted to tell you what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia.  What the hell is the point of my moving up here if you people won't let me relax?  Go help your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles returns to field glasses, spies something.  She looks at him in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on her way out) Fine.  Maybe you can relax in a haunted house.  But I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.  Charles peers after her, brow furrowed. Looks out again at the village.  Uses his field glasses to get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the Bozman Building.  Ernie is out front pol- ishing the brass lion.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHARLES
dialogues.text: He thinks.  Moves the field glasses to punctuate his discovery of the building.  (His eyes never leave field glasses throughout the following.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice building... Bad paint.  Good lines... bad roof.  Good parking... hmmm???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That really registers with him.  Without looking, he dials a familiar number on the phone with one hand, lifts the receiver.  He clacks his teeth together pur- posefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Botco International.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'd like to speak with Maxie Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well tell him that Charles Deetz called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up and continues to spy on Bozman Building. Clacks his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) My God what I could do with that parking.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA AND ADAM
dialogues.text: Very still, they look cautiously to the right and left -- just with their eyes.  They're astounded by what they see, though we don't yet see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Not what I expected when we walked through that door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But it's somewhere without big worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DRAWS BACK and we find that Adam and Barbara are in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most unpleasant waiting room that you ever remember waiting in.  Fifties furniture with broken legs, couches propped up on telephone books. Standing ashtrays with dirty stand.  Linoleum floors patched a hundred times.  National Geographics with the covers torn off.  The "Take a number" registers in the millions.

dialogues.speaker: AS THE CAMERA COMPLETES A CIRCLE OF THE ROOM
dialogues.text: We see a RECEPTIONIST.  She's the quintessential 50's receptionist -- tight sweater, bullet-breasted bra, bleached hair, red lipstick.  She's wearing a ribbon across her breast reading "MISS ARGENTINA" and there are knife slashes across both wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have an appointment, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W... We didn't know how to make one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An appointment for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already?  You just bit the big one nine months ago and you want help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine months?  What difference does that make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Good luck.  You're going to use up all your help vouchers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help vouchers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D-90's.  You spend a hundred and twenty-five years on earth, actually, in that house, during which you get only three class-one D-90 intercessions with Juno.  You probably haven't even read through the manual completely yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why three?

dialogues.speaker: TYPIST
dialogues.text: Behind the Receptionist holds up both hands each of which have only three fingers on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rule Number Three.  Everything comes in threes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait if you don't have an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do we have to wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Juno, your caseworker.  Not that it matters to your type.  But there are all these other people here ahead of you.  I'd say 3 hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiting room is now filled with people.  Dead people, some in fairly awful states.  A cornucopia of carnal shreddage. Adam and Barbara look around for a moment, then very quietly, they reach out to grasp hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Number 54 million, six hundred one.  Ferndock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia kneels down with a screwdriver, a nail file, an ice pick, and a credit card.  She inserts nail file into the door.  She struggles, and after several attempts -- finally uses the ice pick and POP!  The door swings open ominously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia enters.  The room is dim, and filled with dust motes.  There are shadows in all the corners. She bumps into a switch which engages the model sun and moon and that eerily illuminates the model town.  She's frightened, then entranced. She peers at it from different angles, her fear for- gotten.  She notes small tools scattered around an unfinished area.  She continues around the model, oblivious to everything else.  Then... She kicks something.  Ducks under the table and comes up with something, holds it up to the light.  It's the handbook.  She looks through it.  Finds the marked page... looks at the chalk door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam are still holding hands, as if they hadn't moved.  Like waiting for an IRS audit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adam) Is this what happens when you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Receptionist overhears.  She points at Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what happens when YOU die. (points to another corpse) That is what happens when HE dies. That is what happens when THEY die.  It's highly personal.  And I'll tell you something... if I knew then what I know now... I wouldn't have had my little "accident!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up her wrists and smiling at her little joke, wriggles them indicating her slashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all together) Amen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam look at them.  Corpses resume doing what they were doing.  A GRINDING NOISE O.S. -- The Receptionist looks up. Barbara and Adam also look O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Message delivery wire GRINDS along loudly on a pulley.  The actual message is held in the hand of the MESSENGER, a flattened corpse, suspended as if on a shirt clothesline, tire marks on his face and clothing. A major roadkill.  Dust and gravel ground into him.  He smiles wanly at Barbara and Adam as the Receptionist takes a message on a piece of paper and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maitland, party of two!  Take your handbook and go to the sixth door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam upset at the loss of their handbook...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We forgot our handbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is studying the handbook with intense interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from distant downstairs) Lydia, Delia needs your help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia gives one more look at the book, and then goes to the door quickly and silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, Delia says!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head in disgust) Out that way, through the typing pool, down the corridor, sixth door on your left.  Sixth door. Two threes. (shaking her head) Airhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara walk through a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast room of desks arranged in a grid, straight out of "How To Succeed In Business"... Each desk is occupied, too, but most of the secretaries are merely skeletons, or mouldering corpses slumped over their typewriters. Only one secretary, somewhere in the vast grid, is typing slowly, with long pauses between words. The Messenger on his return trip, parallels Barbara and Adam as they walk along.  Barbara can't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I look?  There're no mirrors on this side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be pleasant) Fine, you look fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I've been feeling a little flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs at his own joke as he goes back through the very, very narrow slot in the wall where the line runs.  Adam and Barbara look to the right and left. A vast stack of files slips off a desk and spills out onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam enter corridor. Empty, like a hotel corridor, but all the doors are of different types -- a revolving door, a dutch door, church doors.  They walk past a waist-high window, covered by a roll-up shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred twenty-five years! I can't believe it.  I can't believe they didn't tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bumps into the shade and it rolls up FLAPPING.  She stares in through the window.  Adam peers in it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smouldering, mist-filled room.  From the smoky plasma floats an occasional tortured soul.  Unspeakably SAD MUSIC wafts from within.  They get only a glimpse of the bodies in this horrible human soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, floating up from below, immediately on the other side of the window, a white-crepe face emerges. It seems to be that of a woman, her eyes are red and blue tears rim them.  Her pale skin is covered with a flaking crust of salt.  She wears the saddest look ever.  Her mouth opens plaintively but no sound comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, Adam... what is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reflection joins them on their side of the window.

dialogues.speaker: A SINISTER LITTLE JANITOR
dialogues.text: wizened and efficient, pulls the shade down firmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the lost souls room. A room for ghosts who have been exorcised.  Poor devils.  That's death for the dead.  It's all in the handbook.  Keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man scuttles off.  Adam and Barbara walk on sadly, until they come to a door that looks exactly like the swinging door between the kitchen and dining room of their house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it... the sixth door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled -- Barbara pushes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is dark, quiet -- but the furniture is obviously not theirs, and neither is the decoration. Adam and Barbara exchange glances, and push on through into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, dark.  Everyone's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, we're back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this, everything is different down here.  All our furniture is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you suppose we were waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spot comes on, revealing JUNO -- their caseworker. She's an older woman, no nonsense about her.  Over- dressed in an outfit that includes a blouse with ruffled cuffs.  We will at some point catch a glimpse of her slashed throat -- she smokes heavily.  Occa- sionaly smoke puffs from her cut throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd nearly given up on you.  I was about to leave.  I do have other clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Juno, our caseworker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I evaluate individual cases and determine if help is needed, deserved, and available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need help.  We deserve help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you available?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're very unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect?  You're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd like some help in getting rid of the people who moved in here. Barbara and I worked very hard on this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We probably wouldn't mind sharing the house with people who were --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- like you used to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these people --
