dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates a particularly bad piece of Delia's sculp- ture.  Juno walks around it shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following conversation takes place as Barbara and Adam follow Juno as she looks around the house and ends up in their attic space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things seem pretty quiet here. You should thank God you didn't die in Italy. (checking the file) The Deetzes.  Okay.  Have you been studying the manual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Intermediate Interface chapter on Haunting says it all.  Get 'em out yourself.  It's your house. Haunted houses don't come easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't quite get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juno's watch BUZZES, she stops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard. (refers to her file) Tore your face right off!  Bad news.  It obviously doesn't do any good to pull your heads off in front of people if they can't see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to start simpler, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start simply.  Do what you know. Use your talents.  Practice.  We only help those who help themselves.  Just do a little at a time.  And of course, practice, practice, practice.  It's tricky but -- you weren't murderers by any chance, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity.  Murderers seem to have an easy time of it.  Just look at Amityville. (reminiscing) He was one of my boys.  Didn't have to give that one any lessons. From day one... But I must be off... I've got a plane load of football players crashed in the midwest... they need a lot of help, just with the basics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Points at her head indicating dumbness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If... we have trouble.  What about the guy in the flyer?  Betelge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly interrupt- ing her) Don't say his name, you don't want his help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara look at each other.  Puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... We might...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juno peers into the model cemetery with interest.  A FLY BUZZES around her.  Juno blows it away.  Fly flees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't!  He does not work well with others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  What's he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grave look comes over Juno's face as the light changes to suggest someone telling a ghost story around a campfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to bring it up -- but rather than have you stumble into it and make another mistake, I'll tell you -- (she nervously puffs her cigarette) He was my assistant, but he was a troublemaker... He went out on his own as a free- lance bio-exorcist -- claims to get rid of the living... got into more trouble -- you remember the Chicago Fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara look at each other.  Juno continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He was demoted to a Grade-6 malevolent spirit.  He's been imprisoned on that plane ever since... in fact, I believe he's been sleezing around your cemetery lately.  He can only be brought back by saying his name three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara attempt to interrupt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) But I strongly suggest that you remove the Deetz's yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a final drag on the cigarette and smoke billows out the hole in her throat.  Juno starts to FADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if we need you again, how do we...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juno fades.  Gone.  Barbara goes to the model, looks at the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy is in our cemetery.  Oh, Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds her shoul- ders, calms her) Look, she's right.  We'll just start simple, honey, be tougher. I feel... confident.  C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FOLLOWS ACTION
dialogues.text: The FLY BUZZES.  It lands and crawls along into the model the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLY
dialogues.text: resplendently green and iridescent, pauses and fiddles with its hairy parts.  Starts to walk by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pssstt!  Over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fly stops.  Tilts its multi-eyed head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hands come up from the earth of that grave holding a candy bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't use this.  You should have it.  Flies get so little respect anymore.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLATTERED FLY
dialogues.text: walks over to the grave.  In a flash, the hands grab the struggling fly and dance it like a doll over the grave and then pull it into the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzzz! (turns into) Help me!  Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANIACAL LAUGH grows from the grave.  WIND BLOWS as the Fly disappears.  Ivy whips away from the grave- stone.  We see, for the first time, the chiseled name:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is on the phone.  He has drawings laid out in front of him.  He is at his most urban persuasive, and oddly relaxed -- he is finally in his own element.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxie, have I not always made you money?  I think that is the only real question here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York office, cool design, black couch, and MAXIE DEAN, a 55-year-old, super tan, white-haired wheeler dealer.  Sign says:  CHAIRMAN of BOTCO INDUSTRIES. Maxie looks rich and he looks cool as he talks to Charles.  Behind him, Sarah, his rich-looking blonde wife, is looking at herself in a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Charles -- no one has made me money like you.  Until your nerves went, you were a demon.  It is just that... Winter River, Connecticut is, you'll forgive me, no fucking where.  Why would I invest that kind of money to buy an old building way the hell up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a building!  That's the beauty of it.  I think I can buy the whole town.  These people don't know the value of their property!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we own a whole town full of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, No -- C'mon, Max, you know me.  I've got plans.  You gotta come up here and see, then I'll tell you about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxie isn't much interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sure, Charles, but I am busy here... you know how it was when you were active.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This burns Charles.  But he swallows it.  He hears something in the corridor outside -- a kind of LOW MOANING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Just a minute, Maxie.  Somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No listen... we'll talk about this visiting later, I gotta go, I gotta meeting on the Japanese joint venture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (torn between the MOANING and Maxie) Great idea, Maxie!  Those Japanese could run it for us.  Listen, think right about it, will you? We've almost got the house ready, you bring Sarah with you and I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah, we'll think on it. Bye ya, Charles.  You relax up there, ya hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maxie hangs up.  Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Putz!  Inter River?  My ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles hangs up frustrated.  MOANING INCREASES.  He goes to the door and flings it open. A figure is right there in the doorway -- A ghost under a sheet.  But a "designer" sheet.  He wails away like a banshee.  Eyeholes cut in sheets, Charles jumps, re- covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Lydia!  Is Connecticut so boring that you have to think up shit like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Barbara, she stands back away from the door observ- ing skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I had Maxie Dean on the phone! Darling, Dad's found a way to make some money here while I relax, so scram!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the door, turns around.  Then turns around again, and jerks the door open.  The ghost is retreat- ing, beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) And your mother is going to kill you when she sees that you cut holes in her $300 sheets.  You provoke her you know.  I mean she can be an unreasonable bitch.  But you do provoke her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He SLAMS the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam helps Barbara on with her sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, this is so corny.  Have we been reduced to this?  Sheets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of them as death shrouds. And the moaning is important. Really moan! (imitating Juno) Practice, practice, practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Television still going, Delia asleep with curlers. Adam and Barbara glide inside, go over and stand beside the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep breath... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has her ever-present camera around her neck.  Sud- denly hears MOANS from her parents' room.  Thinking it is sexual, she cringes.  Covers her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross!  How can he stand that woman? (louder) Hey, cut it out!  I'm a child! For God sakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NOISE gets weirder.  Lydia gets interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara moan and groan.  Delia doesn't stir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel really stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not stupid.  We're ghosts. Do you want this woman for breakfast for 125 years?  Moan louder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara moans louder and more weirdly. Delia stirs, sits up, but doesn't open her eyes. Adam and Barbara are excited then... disappointed as Delia fumbles on the bedside table for the remote con- trol device, and without opening her eyes, turns off the television set.  Then she turns over, and is lost to the world totally. Barbara sighs.  She and Adam walk toward the door. When they open it however, Lydia is standing there in her pajamas -- she snaps a FLASH Polaroid -- and Adam and Barbara jump backwards with yelps of fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick!  Sexual perversion!  If you're going to do weird sexual stuff you ought to stay in your bedroom, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia starts back into her room.  Then looks at the developing photograph.  Something catches her eye. Lydia yelps with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy cow!  No feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She screams.  Adam and Barbara scream.  Lydia rushes back toward them, starts flashing pictures. Adam and Barbara run around and are pushed into a corner.  Polaroids fly everywhere. Lydia runs out of film.  She stares at them, panting with fear.  A standoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) A... Are you the guys who're hiding out in the attic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake terror voice) We're ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical, cautious) W... What do you look like under there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara pull shut bedroom door, go out into the hall -- as if to keep from waking Delia with their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three stare at each other tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not scared of Ralph Lauren. Those are sheets.  Are you gross under there?  Are you "Night of the Living Dead" under there? Like all bloody veins and pus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Night of the Living Dead?"  It's a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling off the sheet) If I had seen a ghost at your age, I would have been frightened out of my wits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gross.  Why were you wearing a sheet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're practicing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can actually see us?  Without the sheets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this like a trick question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offended) Of course I can see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wearing contacts... Also I read through the "Handbook for the Recently Deceased."  It says that live people ignore the strange and unusual... I, myself, am strange and unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tenderly) You look like a regular girl to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia blushes.  Barbara smiles warmly.  She is begin- ning to like Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read our book?  Could you follow it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you creeping around Delia's bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were trying to scare your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepmother.  I'm very sensitive about being related to reptiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You can't scare her.  She's sleeping with Prince Valium tonight. (defiantly) I stole the key to your attic, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we better talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam's rigged up the moon, and stars, too.  Adam and Barbara and Lydia stand just beyond the fringes of the town, dimly lighted giants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did this?  You carved all these little figures and houses and things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) I certainly did.  I'd finish it too, but... I don't get out much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this used to be your house, I bet.  Why do you want to scare everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to frighten you away. (a little embarrassed) So that you'll move out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know the Deetz's very well, do you?  My father bought this place.  He never walks away from equity.  Why don't you leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't.  We haven't left the house since the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral.  God, you guys really are

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: dead! (fascinated) What was it like?  The funeral. Did you cry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren't there.  The handbook says funerals aren't for the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, if this is true this is amazing!  I kinda like it up here.  Can I visit you sometimes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know... We don't get many visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're really a pretty girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia flushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... I don't think it would be a very good idea if you told your parents that we're up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you think it would scare them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia starts to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You tell them that we are desperate horrible ghoulish creatures who will stop at nothing to get back our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks him up and down) Wait a minute, what if this is a dream?  Can you do any tricks to prove I'm not dreaming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara shakes her head, a little ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, if you are real ghosts, you better get another routine, those sheets suck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sneaks a smile at Barbara and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big ugly machine is doing something unnecessary to the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FAST-TICKING CLOCK is a timer.  Lydia is making Polaroid enlargements.  She's quick and expert at this. She's examining a print with a magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia shrieks.  Going through the dirty clothes, she's just come across the sheets with the eye holes in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia!  Lydia!  My hands are shredded from doing the laundry, and now I have to deal with your vandalism!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, pounding up from the basement with the wet print, collides with Delia, rushing down from the sec- ond floor with the scissored sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, honest to God I'm going to kill you.  I'm having a party tonight.  I'm cooking, I can't get servants.  Do I need angst?  No, I certainly do not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia speeds by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You owe me three-hundred bucks, Lydia!  Don't go running to your father, you worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia rushes in.  Charles is working furiously on a word processor, amidst an array of maps and plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.  Do you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Except when you creep around in your mother's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepmother's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this is... I mean, this is the weirdest --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, I don't know what it is with you and these pratical jokes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a joke!  That sheet was full of ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him the photo.  He looks.  Lydia points out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) No feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You don't believe me.  That sheet was full of ghosts.  They live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles begins to scroll through computer program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissing it) Very clever, Lydia.  Now would you please -- I'll tell you what... I know!  You're bored, right?  You take that camera and your bike and photograph every building in town.  Don't tell anyone what it's for... (handing her a wad of bills) Here, take some cash and go do it.  How's that?  You want to stretch, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia exits, with determination.  Charles looks up on the wall and runs his finger over a plat map of Winter River, just like Adam's in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look at the size of these lots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam peers at the map, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this guy doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara follows Lydia out.  Adam thinks, intrigued. Exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia is frantically preparing for the evening's dinner party.  Lydia is very much in her way, trying to show her the photographs.  Delia isn't looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you are doing this to me!  Ghosts.  I am giving a dinner party for seven people tonight.  Otho has agreed to come back for the demolition of the attic.  My agent, Bernard, is bringing some woman who writes for "Art in America."  In fact, no one here tonight has not been in "Vanity Fair."  Except you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) I told them you were too mean to be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare talk to others about me.  I'm an artist!  The only thing that scares me is being embarrassed in front of my friends.  Do you know how hard it is to get civilized people to set foot in this part of Connecticut? Not a solitary word of this pubescent tripe to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia exits angrily. CAMERA HINGES.  Barbara is watching, horrified at Delia's occupation of her (Barbara's) kitchen.  Adam appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia's trying, but they don't believe her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got photos, Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, you had a photo of Big Foot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is different.  Eventually she'll take someone to the attic. And then what?  We've got to try to contact this guy Betelmyer.  We gotta get some help, hon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks intently through the book. Barbara's eye is caught by something in the model cemetery.  She moves over and sees a small gravestone lit up by neon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam comes over.  Looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do that one... Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him.  Look... Betelgeuse... Betelgeuse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Adam, "should I?" Adam chews his lip thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead... third time's a charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a deep breath) Betelgeuse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZAP!  They are transported into the model graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIND BLOWS --  With shovels and lanterns, Adam and Barbara are unlikely gravediggers.  The mechanized clouds move in the sky across the mechanical moon, throwing weird shadows everywhere.  Ground fog creeps slowly along the graves.  It is so eerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three times.  Powerful number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing in front of grave) Bet... el... geuse.  What an awful name.  I thought it was like -- you know.  The juice of beetles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam cringes too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where is he?  What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks down at the grave.  Knocks on the stone. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anything been simple so far? From the look of the shovel, we dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Adam.  I don't have gloves. My nails keep getting longer. I'll break them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands her a shovel anyway.  She digs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're almost down six feet.  By now they are both almost out of sight in the grave.  Inside the grave -- Adam suddenly hits wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lean down and brush dirt off a brass plate on the coffin. "BETELGEUSE"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should knock first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight TREMOR shakes them.  They look at each other and try to scramble from the grave.

dialogues.speaker: TOPSIDE
dialogues.text: They just barely crawl out when a mouldering corpse springs out of the grave and jumps on Barbara's back, and plants a thousand-year-old kiss on her lips.  She screams and burbles.  Adam pulls the corpse off her back.  The corpse does a Three Stooges hammer on Adam's head. Adam staggers backward, unhurt but shocked.  All three stop.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CORPSE
dialogues.text: Something unreal about him, almost mechanical.  Then the corpse, grinning insanely at them, flies straight up into the air over their heads.  He CRASHES against the tombstone... And Adam and Barbara see the corpse is only a huge marionette on a string and pole.  A LAUGH comes from behind the gravestone.

dialogues.speaker: PUPPETEER BETELGEUSE
dialogues.text: steps out.  He looks like someone who just crawled out from under a rock.  This is one slippery customer. Betelgeuse speaks in a rapid polyglot, choosing words and phrases from every slang in the world.  Barbara is mighty uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no!  I'm rolling.  I'm a businessman.  I'm the man what am.  Beeetel Jooose!  Who do I gotta kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't kill anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get some people out of our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bio busting.  I love it.  Who do I gotta kill?  Family -- right? Obnoxious, I bet. (contorting face) Mommie, daddy, piglets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey you've been on Saturn! (brushing yellow dust off her) I hate those Sandworms!  Yecchhh! I've lost a lot of buddies to Sandworms. (back to work) So a daughter?  She got good legs? God I love a young leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air blows up Barbara's dress, exposing her legs.  He leers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's only fourteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... acts like she's thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing hands) How does she feel about short old men with dirty ears?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is grossed out and increasingly uneasy.  Beetle Juice senses it and gets back to business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you, the dead, want me, the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: undead, to throw the live guys -- Mommie, Daddy and Lolita, who might not mind a tumble with an older guy, out into the cold? Even though they have paid hard casharoonie for your dump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... the Deetzes are destroying our house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scolding sarcasm) You Maitlands are the backbone of the afterlife.  So what's my cut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you scare them off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beetle Juice looks offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, scary?  You be the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swirls his face and shoulders into a horrifying image.  Pleased, he laughs at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (decisively) Honey.  Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go?  What d'ya mean?  We need help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't.  We can work something out ourselves.  We just have to try harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.  Let's not be squeamish, missy.  You rang my bell, you gotta lick the pump.  I'm rolling!

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: grabs Adam.  Betelgeuse is getting mad.  Not pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks, be reasonable here.  I'm at your service.  You be the judge. I'm a harmless guy.  Try me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.  Home.  Home!

dialogues.speaker: ZAP
dialogues.text: They are gone.  Betelgeuse is furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fresh corpse creeps!  Who do you think you are?... Walking away from a professional?

dialogues.speaker: BETELGEUSE
dialogues.text: walks to a tree and kicks it hard.  The whole huge tree falls, KABLOOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small tree falls in the model.  Adam, across the room, walks over and straightens it. He looks at Barbara who is poring over the handbook. Making notes.  Counting out procedures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I think that was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not going to expose that little girl to that... pervert down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proud of herself) Just a hunch... remember things come in threes -- three times in, three times out... I'm getting the hang of this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we really pissed him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we let him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've changed my mind... I feel really confident.  We're getting better at this stuff.  We can scare them off ourselves -- tonight!  I've got an idea. You're going to love it... I'm going to hate it.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: turns to look down at the model again.  Straightens the tree.  Turns away.  We can see a tiny light moving through the tiny model forest towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  But that Betelgeuse sure seemed mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Hi ho, hi ho, it's off to work I go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner for seven, as promised.  Everything looks very nice.  Deetzes are in control and in their element. The element is neurotic-chic. Some of the guests are affecting distaste for having had to make the long drive to Connecticut.  There's a bitchy feud going on between GRACE, the "Art In Amer- ica" writer, and BERNARD, Delia's agent, that threatens to become a full-scale war. Otho is drunkish and engaged in his third favorite occupation -- direct attacks on the personal weaknesses of his friends.  He's singled out his victim, BERYL, the editor for Ballantine, a frail-looking woman who is dressed "artistically."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Beryl) Well, darling, you can only have a hysterectomy once, so why don't you tell us what you really went into the hospital for last week?  Or dare I ask, is that a nose "nouveau?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (privately; to Otho) Otho, you've got to help me get Maxie Dean up here.  I have a deal that could make all of us very comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a cloven-hooved beast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's your cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am ashamed to say he is.  Look, nothing short of giving away free sacks of money would get him up here, Charles.  And Sarah?  Forget it.  You can't get her out of Bergdorf's with plastic explosives. (still on Beryl's case) I just hope it wasn't yet another of your dreary suicide attempts.  You know what they say about people who who commit suicide.  In the afterlife, they become civil servants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho!  I didn't know you were into the supernatural?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you remember!  After my stint with the living theatre.  I was one of New York City's leading paranormal researchers until the bottom dropped out of the business in '72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sick to death of this blowhard) Paranormal... Is that what they're calling your kind now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia watches Otho thoughtfully.  Suddenly very cur- ious. Delia senses that Lydia might talk ghosts here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a threat; quietly to Lydia) Don't you dare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw some ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Lydia tried to play a most amusing joke on me this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tried to convince me that this house is haunted.  Kids.  Kids. Kids!  I love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho's glance sharpens at this.  Everyone else listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By ghosts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By what else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing it away) In sheets yet.  Designer sheets. They --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, seeing things aren't going well for Delia, proposes a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I propose a toast to our intrepid friends.  Who braved the expressway and fourteen toll booths to visit us.  May your buildings go condo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All lift their wineglasses.  All drink.  All synchro- nously spit out their wine.  All together now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yechhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles lifts the wine bottle from the cooler.  Disgust spans the room. ON bottle -- it bears the familiar spread wings of Thunderbird!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunderbird wine?  My God, Delia, don't you even have a Safeway up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified; but recovering) Joke Joke!  Charles get the good wine and I'll serve the shrimp. It's a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia stares a spike through Lydia.  Delia and Charles rush into the kitchen.  Otho looks at his glass and peers at Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia rushes to get the sushi.  Charles finds some good wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rapidly; furious) Lydia switched wines.  Charles -- if you do not agree right now, to boarding school, you can forget having what you call sex -- ever again in your natural lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods reluctantly.  She rushes back to guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is looking around curiously.  Delia and Charles rush back in with sushi and good wine.  Delia pours for Bernard, the obvious connoisseur.  He tastes the wine. All wait.  Is it Kerosene du Pape?  He smiles.  All smile. Otho is more interested in Lydia's story.  He leans toward her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Lydia... Favor us about your ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Do not encourage this little... person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Delia, lighten up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been without therapy up here and I will not allow her to ruin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then:

dialogues.speaker: DELIA
dialogues.text: Something comes over her -- she straightens, then crouches a little, her hand sweeps across in front of her, almost mechanically.  And then our Delia Deetz, unable to help herself, leaves the whitebread world behind and possessed, sings in someone else's voice, a rich, NEGRO TENOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If I didn't care, More than words could say."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia's eyes widen.  MUSIC UP.  All the guests are spellbound. Charles, too, has the beat -- The Ink Spots in his eyes. In a voice not his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If my every prayer, did not begin and end with just your name."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia is shocked.  She looks at Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, stop me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is cut short by her powerful inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I could not be true to you beyond compare."

dialogues.speaker: ALL THE GUESTS
dialogues.text: except Lydia, are possessed to become the chorus.  They stand by their chairs, they spin in perfect Motown choreography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (except Lydia) "Shoo doo wop.  Shoo doo wop."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If I didn't care... for you..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shoo doo wop.  Shoo doo wop."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of sheer delight comes across Lydia's face, unlike anything we have previously seen.  She dances and claps her hands in time with the music.  She is in teen heaven. NOTE:  Delia and the guests are fully aware of their singing/actions, but helpless to stop themselves.  While it is funny, it is nevertheless just a little frighten- ing. Lydia excitedly looks around the room to see if she can see the ghosts.  She can't. Now the song pauses... Everyone tries to recover for a shocked second.  Instead, the tempo changes. As the tempo quickens, the guest/chorus is syncopated like alternating pistons as they are pushed and pulled into their chairs.  They sing throughout.

dialogues.speaker: THE SONG
dialogues.text: crashes to its end.  Bernard looks down at his shrimp cocktail.  The shrimp draped over the rice roll suddenly rears up like a hand and, making a tiny fist, grabs his dangling tie and... smash -- WIDER -- All the guests are punched by the shrimp, back over their chairs to the ground.  They are stunned.  Suddenly everyone runs frightened into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara with huge smiles on their faces, dance the bugaloo then hug and kiss on the landing in front of the attic.  Door is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's watch 'em scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the attic and run to the window.  Look out over the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: YARD OF HOUSE
dialogues.text: filled with the cars of the guests, as well as Delia and Charles' vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any minute now.  They'll all run screaming.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: They wait.  Nothing moving outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Ink Spots were wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your shrimp was remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shrimp?  I did the wine. Didn't you do the sushi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N... No, I just did the Ink Spots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did the?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timid KNOCK at the door of the attic. Barbara glances at Adam.  They don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from outside the door) It's me.  Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, puzzled, goes to the door and opens it.  Lydia is standing there, sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) They'd like for you to come downstairs.  Delia says you can pick any sheets you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guests are sitting expectantly.  The photographs are being passed around.  The wheels are turning in Charles' mind --  he sees a gold mine.  Everyone speaks at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does indicate a marvelously urbane sense of humor on the part of these ghosts -- that they actually appear in sheets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dealing with Tracy and Hepburn here, a very sophisticated pair.  We must protect them, treat them with respect.  Nurture them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will pay big money for this.  Right, Grace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Charles, I want to know why you didn't tell me about this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (now changing her tune) We were waiting for proof. Lydia's photographs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is scheming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) What are you all talking about? We... we just got a little drunk, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how drunk you get, you cannot sound like the Ink Spots. (to Charles) Charles, this is it!  You can get Maxie Dean up here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles plots and plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife Sarah loves the supernatural.  I did a reading for her just last week.  Told her her jowls would tighten soon.  I mean she will make him sprint up here in his helicopter if you can produce ghosts for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Enquirer" has offered fifty thousand dollars for absolute proof of life after death.  I'll send them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Delia's agent!  I've lost money for years on her work.  If anything actually happened here, I'll handle it, thank you.  But not until I see some real proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia appears at the base of the stairs.  Everyone stops squabbling, looks at her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want to come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard shakes his head as if all this were an elaborate hoax.  He harumphs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the reason is they were trying to scare you, and you didn't get scared --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we weren't scared. (looking around) Just a little startled.  One of those shrimp dropped down my Kamali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard is now convinced this whole business was a put- on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Total collective hallucination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a little tipsie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was not a hallucination, people.  This was real, really totally real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, they were rather spectacular effects -- for Connecticut, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All presences have a home space.  A place where they live, so to speak. Where do they hide out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) The attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attic room is locked --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ghosts.  They do what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous!  Otho Fenlock's "Locked Door" ghosts!  Probably committed suicide up there -- hanging like beeves from the rafters.  I'm totally enchanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernard gathers Grace and Beryl and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia, you are a flake.  You have always been a flake.  I'm packing up and going back to the tricks of the city.  That I can manage.  If you must frighten people, do it with your sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.  Delia is horrified and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  I'm going to get to the bottom of this!  Lydia, is this some high-tech trick of yours?  I want you to take us up there tout sweet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia, Charles, Otho and Lydia -- creep, creep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Shhh.  They're in there?  God, they live like animals.  This is where they've been hiding out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia nods.  Delia suddenly, brashly pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) All right, you dead people!  Come on out, or we'll break down this door and drag you out on the ropes you hanged yourself with!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh.  They didn't commit suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. What matters is I've got a roomful of guests down there, who think I'm a fraud. (to Lydia) I am going to teach you something here Lydia.  You've got to take the right tone in things like this, or people -- whether they're dead or alive -- people will walk all over you. (loud) Come on out, or I will make death so miserable that you will wish you had never lived!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia pounds on door, which opens with an eerie CREAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is pushed in first.  She looks around.  Delia, Charles and Otho come in next, carefully.  One by one they straighten up and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper) So where are they, Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia shrugs, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-handedly) Answer your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you guys.  These ghosts are really nice people.  I think we scared them off.  Let's just leave them alone.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is suddenly transfixed.  He stares at the model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the whole damn town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gather around.  Lydia is a little sad as she looks at the empty room and the model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that detail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the tiny figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at all that parking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Leave their stuff alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not here, Lydia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head.  Otho spots the handbook.  Palms it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never been so embarrassed... They haven't gone for good, have they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia is suddenly out the door, urging them all outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Everyone out of there.  If they're in there somewhere, I don't want to scare them away.  Come on now, stay out of there.  We've got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho pockets the handbook secretly as everyone exits. Delia carefully closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA EASES OVER TO THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: We see two pairs of hands, white-knuckled, gripping the window sill from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam are hanging outside the window. CAMERA EASES BACK to see that instead of hanging from the house -- They are hanging from a ledge over The Inferno --

dialogues.speaker: ON INFERNO
dialogues.text: circles of rosy hell.  Several devilish Monsters slaver up at them, hoping for new meat for the furnace.  Small geysers spurt foul gasses.

dialogues.speaker: WINDS
dialogues.text: BLOW hard on Adam and Barbara.  They struggle to hold on and pull themselves back up and into the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juno, help!  Juno!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After nearly falling, Adam barely saves Barbara and they finally make it up, and disappear into the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia, Charles and Otho all start down the stairs, one by one.  All are holding the handrail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, I will never forgive you for embarrassing me in front of my social inferiors.  You help us with these ghosts or you'll be sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fixing on Otho) Now, let's get back to business.  I I want to get Maxie Dean and Sarah up here immediately.  I can make history here!  I'm going to turn this sleepy little backward town into a leading supernatural research center... and amusement park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) I cannot believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia will cook...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'll bring the wine... and the business plan.  And Lydia -- you'll bring the ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I can't bring the ghosts.  They're not here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Otho, could you actually... do something with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pats the handbook under his coat) Perhaps... if I were properly motivated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's slavery and murder.  You don't know them.  They're nice people!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV -- down the handrail, as they walk downstairs. Lydia lags behind, sullen.

dialogues.speaker: LOWER END OF THE HANDRAIL
dialogues.text: lifts, and turns.  The handrail has become a long, fat, diamond-backed snake -- unlike any we have ever seen. It flashes terrifying steel teeth and a red-feathered comb.  It turns and HISSES at them.

dialogues.speaker: ON DELIA
dialogues.text: She screams as she looks down at her hand on the rail -- it grips the scaly, throbbing, dripping body of the snake.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: just gets longer and nastier as it turns back in the air, up the stairs toward them.  Its tail circles Delia and spins her like a top.  When she stops -- the snake gives her a big wet snake kiss.

dialogues.speaker: SNAKE
dialogues.text: snaps Otho in the behind.  It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: rears up and spreads a red-comb and HISSES loudly.

dialogues.speaker: ALL THREE
dialogues.text: of them fall over each other trying to escape.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: hovers horribly over them.  Grabs Charles in its coils and squeezes him hard -- his fearful face reddens, then it suspends Charles over the edge of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've come for your daughter, Chuck!

dialogues.speaker: HE
dialogues.text: leers at Lydia and drops Charles like a rock over the bannister.  Charles screams.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: Grins at a terrified Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: SNAKE
dialogues.text: rears back for a strike, when suddenly, like thunder. One word is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse!  Betelgeuse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse!

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: looks up with familiar eyes.  At top of stairs stands an angry Barbara. What happens next is almost too fast for the eye to see.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNAKE
dialogues.text: shrinks and turns back into the regular mahogany hand- rail.

dialogues.speaker: BETELGEUSE
dialogues.text: or his outline, whips up the stairs, through the door, and is gone like a rocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RRRatt shit!

dialogues.speaker: OTHO AND DELIA
dialogues.text: rush downstairs -- Lydia is terrified.  She runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you!  I thought you were my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia screams and runs down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) I hate all of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, Barbara returns to the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam and Barbara are exhausted.  Agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great choice we've got here.  We get to spend the next century either hanging out that window or doing parlor tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam is working with the model town.  Barbara is pac- ing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll leave now.  That snake was a pretty nasty customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might have hurt somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he didn't.  We've got him where we want him.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MODEL
dialogues.text: A column of water shoots high in the air. Adam rushes over to the model -- looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse has run a beat-up old pickup into a fire hydrant.  He stands nearby, hopping mad; shakes his fist at Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pansy-assed cretins!  How dare you do that to me.  I coulda finished the job!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ATTIC
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam, obviously disturbed, look at one another with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thin and pip- ing voice) Why did you stop me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like Charles Deetz particularly, but you could have killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I've been bottled up for six hundred years.  Every dog has his day.  This is my town.  I need a night to howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish!  I nearly scored with that little blonde.  I need me a short little queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry, Barbara reaches down into the model and plucks Betelgeuse up. Barbara lifts him up toward her, squeezing him slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave her alone, you horrid little prick!

dialogues.speaker: BETELGEUSE IN BARBARA'S HAND
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse grins.  Suddenly large spikes shoot out all over his body, piercing the skin of Barbara's palm and fingers.  Barbara's blood is a rich pink. She squeals and releases the evil spirit and he plum- mets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse lands on the town common.  Betelgeuse is defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  Make my millenium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the tinny strains of "Honky Tonk Angel" as if from down the street.  He turns around to follow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This burg got a cathouse?  I'm getting anxious if you know what I mean.  Six hundred years and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the corner to a whorehouse, with women -- women with demon horns -- hanging out of the window, beckoning.  Betelgeuse rubs his hands together and swaggers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara aghast, watching this from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam!  Why did you build a whore house?  Have you ever been to...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't finish -- a strong WIND blows through the attic, nearly knocking Barbara and Adam over.  They close their eyes against the gale. When they open their eyes again, they're no longer in the attic.  They're in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cubicle in a much larger office.  Miss Argentina swishes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you have got her steaming now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.  There are other special workers.  The place is really, really busy.  Adam and Barbara sit down to wait.  Juno storms through with a sheaf of papers.  She sees them.  She is steaming mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whorehouse was my idea.  I want Betelgeuse out of the picture!  We've got some serious talking to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people have really screwed up!  I received word that you allowed yourselves to be photographed.  And you let Betelgeuse out and didn't put him back, and you let Otho get ahold of the handbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handbook?  When...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing tirade) Never trust the living!  We cannot have a routine haunting like yours provide incontrovertible visual proof of existence beyond death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we didn't know --

dialogues.speaker: A BUNCH OF FOOTBALL PLAYERS
dialogues.text: follow Juno like hungry dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Coach, where's the men's room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I'm not your coach.  He survived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need a men's room. You're not no man no more.  But Coach, let me get this -- What's our curfew over here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start squabbling.  Juno has to wrangle them into another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles sits at the table with a small bandage on his head.  Delia takes off her Gucci belt and whips it on a chair absent-mindedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like we've been at war, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least insofar as we have our first casualty.  Me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho'll know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he going to do?  Viciously rearrange their environment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho knows just as much about the supernatural as he knows about interior design.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope he knows how to produce those damn ghosts for Max and Sarah... Because I've bought options on property all over town. I need Max's financing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't tell Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's in with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark.  The bedroom curtains have been closed. DRAMATIC OPERA MUSIC builds throughout. Lydia melodramatically dressed in a long black dress appears carrying a candle.  She is softly crying. She sits at her dressing table, the candlelight shows her writing paper.  She begins a very dramatic letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at it and crumpling the paper, starts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I am utterly... alone.  You have sealed my fate with your betrayal. I can no longer stand to be used like a puppet between two deceitful worlds.  By the time you read this, I will be gone, having jumped off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scratches that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... having plummeted off the Winter River Bridge.  Then you will know that I am no longer a toy in your petty feuds.  Goodbye, Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tear falls on the paper as she folds it and puts it in an envelope.  OPERA MUSIC BUILDS AND CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia slowly makes a copy of the suicide note.  The green of the Xerox light falls eerily on her sad face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia at bottom of attic stairs.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS AND DOOR AT TOP
dialogues.text: They look ominous.  She starts upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Lydia peers in. The room is empty.  Lydia comes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears SOMETHING.  Looks all around the room. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mr. and Mrs. Maitland?  I've come for the last time? (laying note on table) Where are you?  Barb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia looks around, then peers into model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Think small.  I'm talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny Betelgeuse on the roof of a building, wearing a silk dressing gown, looking like he just dragged him- self out of bed.  One of the horned whores is nude, sunbathing in the corner, and Betelgeuse drapes a blanket over her.  Lydia's face looms enormous in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie, they are dead, dead, deadski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they're dead.  They're ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean they've gone. Decamped.  Split.  Vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd they go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The happy hunting ground.  Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a spirit too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of.  High spirit.  Heh heh. Listen, cookie, I've been trapped in this burg for hundreds of years.  All I want is to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?  Over here?  On my side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scheming quickly) Well, yes, of course.  It's great over here.  You'll meet all the greats.  James Dean.  Sid Vicious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it can't be any worse than my life here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sinister, encouraging her) That's right.  They treat you like scum, I bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help you from this side, but here's how we do it.  So simple.  Say my name three times.  That's all.  I'll be all yours.  Then I'll bring you over here in style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know what your name is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minor problem.  The rules.  I can't tell it to you.  But.. do you know how to play charades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds up two fingers in a V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse holds up one finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) First word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse puts two fingers on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Three syllables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, dummy.  Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fingers are so small I can't see them.  First word -- two syllables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I don't know what that signal means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means look behind you, bimbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia looks behind her.  A greet beetle the size of a Volkswagen is crouching.  Its feathery antennae reach out toward her menacingly.  Lydia yelps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beetle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good girrrl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POP!  The beetle disappears.  Betelgeuse holds up two fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still shaken) Second word.  Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apprehensive, she jumps when a simple carton of orange juice materializes.  Orange juice pours out into a ghostly glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast?  Orange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orange juice disappears.  He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breakfast beetle?  Beetle?  Beetle fruit?  Fruit bat?  Fruit Battle? Volkswagen?  Fruit wagon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing you are a beautiful kid.  You are dumb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse does the signal for "Now Put Them Together."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not!  Beetle... Juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping with delight) That's it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Beetle Juice?  Yecch! That's as bad as Deeelia Deeetz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's spelled different, but basically... Now you said it twice, just one more time.  And I'll be free. (sinister) And then you'll be free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, puzzled, gets the magnifying glass and peers at him.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS UGLY FACE BIG IN THE GLASS
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse jumps in the air, his robe parts -- we don't see anything, but maybe Lydia does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, you're anatomically correct!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recognizing something about him) You were the snake!  Right?  I know.  It was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't.  I don't take orders from Smurfs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you like to be married to... the King...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... Elvis?... (boasting) You know, ever since he came over he and I have been just like this. (crosses his fingers) I can arrange it.  Just say my name one more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks about that one.  Shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, No... I need to talk to Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, cookie, just say my name.  I can get her. (rubbing his horny little hands together) That and so much more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia walks around thinking for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else did you say is over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juno staring at them, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... or no?  Do you want the Deetzes out or in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Betelgeuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget him.  He'll remain with his whores until someone calls him. You need to worry about people like Otho.  There are a lot of phony trance mediums.  They usually can't make the formulas work, but if Otho stumbles on the right words in that handbook... he could hurt you.  As in -- exorcism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) In plain English -- that's death for the dead.  I don't care what it takes, just get them out of there now.  It's not pretty, but -- that's death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam stands to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wait a minute.  Let's see what you're going to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at Juno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ... to scare her.  I want to make sure it's not some silly parlor trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara looks at Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do the hard part, hon.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM
dialogues.text: reluctantly pulls on his face, and contorts it into a living, breathing, horror.  Juno is even a little repulsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.  Not bad.  Now you?  Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reluctantly does with her face a minor version of Adam's horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay.  You look great!  Now go clean house.  And don't forget the photographs and the damned handbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam slowly stand and walk out the door. Barbara/Monster looks back pleadingly.  Football players flood into Juno's office.  One PARTICULARLY DUMB PLAYER has a revelation.  (He's pretty grisly, maybe sat too close to the engine.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach!  Coach, I don't think we survived the crash!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Adam look at each other and continue out the door.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE JUNO'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: They enter a long dark hallway.  They suddenly find themselves standing in front of Lydia's room.  Adam/ Monster looks at Barbara/Monster as he grabs the door- knob.  She stops him.  Tears fall down her sad ghostly face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam.  I can't do it.  I like that little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late.  Sometimes things just work out this way.  We have to, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't.  We can rebel or something.  We'll just stay up there in our room.  I'll read, you can build on the model.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes up the stairs, toward the attic.  He follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  We can't, honey.  Our house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets to the door.  Grabs the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be with Lydia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is standing over the model, about to say Betelgeuse's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Beetle... J...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara/Monster, horrified, screams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: !  Lydia, stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam/Monster runs to grab her.  Lydia is terrified. Screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it!  Rat shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betelgeuse slips off the roof into a patch of thorny bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia screams, Adam/Monster tries to calm her.  Lydia struggles and, thinking she is being attacked, runs out the door.  Smack into Barbara/Monster. Barbara catches her, frightens Lydia even more. Barbara holds onto her as she struggles.  Barbara/ Monster slowly changes back into regular Barbara. Lydia sees who it is and she hugs her.  Like mother and daughter. ON ADAM - slowly returning to himself.  He smiles slightly at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lily-livered bleeding hearts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry we frightened you. What were you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He... Beetle Jui...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara quickly puts her hand over her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He said if I let him out he would take me over to the other side to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Lydia, we're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be dead, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) No you don't!  No... Lydia... Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause, dramatically but for real) Life is just... unliveable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara hugs her.  She fumbles for words.  This is an unusual situation, a dead person talking a live person out of killing herself.  She rocks Lydia a little. Barbara looks at Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia, believe me... we know... all the hard stuff is the same over here.  You're going to be who you are... whether you're alive or dead... and over here -- it's... It's flat... there's no food, no colors... you can't smell the flowers. (thinking) If we knew then what we know now... we'd have been more careful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the style of the dead receptionist) ... we wouldn't have had our little accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia looks at Barbara lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So never let Beetlejuice out -- never.  Besides... (looking at Adam) We're thinking about letting everyone stay... you and your father and mother can stay too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles and says slowly) Step... mother.

dialogues.speaker: ADAM/MONSTER
dialogues.text: is not sure, huffs around a little.  He is trying to change back into Adam, except for his nose, which remains like a beak for a minute.  Finally, it changes too. Lydia and Barbara laugh at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without noticing Lydia, Otho and Charles push in through the door and grab the model.  They take it out the door. Adam is beside himself.  Doesn't know what to do. Barbara stops him from taking action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.  I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks suspiciously at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I really don't.  I'll go find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia runs through the hallway and into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia walks into a presentation in progress.  Sitting around the table are Otho, Maxie, and Delia.  Sarah Dean is there, too.  She looks around Lydia hoping for ghosts.  Sarah is heavily made up, smells bad. Lydia's photos of the sheeted ghosts are blown up and standing on a nearby easel.  Charles, over the model with a pointer, is lost in mid-sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- In short, I've got options to buy enough of Main Street to control the city council for a hundred years.  And at the prices I'm talking about, if it all fell apart tomorrow, we just move out and sell to the Arabs and we still come out... I've talked to Ed Cornwall about a wax museum, here... in Thanksgiving Park... Ed's the man who made the talking Jesse Jackson statue. And I've got a museum dedicated to 50 Great Moments in the Paranormal -- and parenthetically, D-Con wants to the right to start an insect zoo here in the old hardware store. (seeing Lydia) Lydia, did you finally decide to join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all give her an oily smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I am just finishing the first phase presentation about our little project here.  Then we'll take a stretch and invite our friends... to meet your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah gets Maxie's attention and unable to contain her excitement, silently urges him to get on with the ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they here yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Charles, let's cut the bullcorn.  We're here to see ghosts.  This whole ghost town museum and such like follows a train, if you've got the engine... so let's see your goddamned engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're... not here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling apologetically) Nonsense, every time she says that, the paint peels, and some wild creature tries to kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning) We've got these pictures, Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really... they said they might come back and all of us could live in peace if you agreed not to tease them or make them do silly tricks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is disappointed.  She goes to Maxie.  Delia takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's become a little emotional about all this.  No counseling up here.  But we aren't relying on her.  No, we rely on professionals.  We have... Otho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole room turns to Otho.  Who is scribbling some- thing and mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they still here, Otho?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho looks up; he missed the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they still here, Otho?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they're still here.  They're just not showing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're probably guilty about what they did to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not these people!  They are ruthless!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care from guilt.  I just want to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Otho, can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's tricky, but I think I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dramatically produces the handbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia begins to think about this scene and she shifts to another point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!  What am I worried about?  Otho, you can't even change a tire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the challenge) I'll need something personal of theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to go to the Goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon stares down icily through gray clouds.  Wind up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistful) You know, I've been thinking.  I could teach Lydia to sew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little black party dresses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
